column1: Of princes shall outlive this powerful rhyme
But you shall shine more bright in these contents
Than unswept stone besmeared with sluttish time.
When wasteful war shall statues overturn
And broils root out the work of masonry
Nor Mars his sword nor war’s quick fire shall burn
The living record of your memory.
'Gainst death and all oblivious enmity
Shall you pace forth; your praise shall still find room
Even in the eyes of all posterity
That wear this world out to the ending doom.
So
column2: till the judgment that yourself arise

column1: I see thy grievèd heart. Thy sad aspect
Hath from the number of his banished years
Plucked four away.  To Bolingbroke. Six frozen winters spent
Return with welcome home from banishment.

Four lagging winters and four wanton springs
End in a word; such is the breath of kings.

He shortens four years of my son’s exile.
But little vantage shall I reap thereby;
For

column1: [Lampatho:] By this hand I will.

column1: [Lampatho:] By this hand I will.

Thou more then sweet glove
Vnto my more sweet Love
Suffer me to store with kisses
This empty lodging yt now misses
The your rosy hand yt have the

column1: In quantity equals not one of yours.
See how this river comes me cranking in
And cuts me from the best of all my land
A huge half-moon
I’ll have the current in this place dammed up
And here the smug and silver Trent shall run
In a new channel
It shall not wind with such a deep indent
To rob me of so rich a bottom here.

bound for England; if your name be Horatio, as I am;"unedited";"John Marston";"The Malcontent";"217; Epilogue [normalized spelling].";"";"";"";"";"English";"Your modest silence
Makes me thus speak: A voluntary illness
Is merely senseless but unwilling error
Such as proceeds from too rash youthfull fervour
May well be called a fault but not a sin
Rivers take names from Founts where they begin.
Then let not too severe an eye peruse
The slighter breaks of our reformed Muse
Who could herself
But that she knows tis easy to correct.
Though some men's labour: troth
As long as wisdom's not professed
Then till in others happier Muse appears
Till his Thalia feast your learned ears
To whose desert-full Lamps pleased fates impart.
<i>Art above Nature
Receive this peace which hope
<i>He that knows most

column1: Makes me thus speake: A voluntary illnesse
Is meerely sensles but vnwilling error
Such as proceedes from too rash youthfull feruour
May will be cald a fault but not a sinne
Riuers take names from Fountes where they begin.
Then let not too seuere an eye peruse
The slighter brakes of our reformed Muse
Who could her selfe
But that she knowes tis easie to correct.
Though some mens labour: troth to erre fit
As long as wisdom's not professd
Then till in others happier Muse appeares
Till his Thalia feast your learned eares
To whose desertfull Lampes pleasd fates impart.
Art aboue Nature
Receiue this peece which hope
He that knows most

column1: Leander: t'were excellent; and praise be to my memory
It has reached half a dozen lines for the purpose:
Well
One is no Number; Maids are nothing then
Without the sweet society of Men.
Will thou live single still? one shalt thou be
Though never singling Hymen couple thee.
Wild Savages that drink of running Springs
Thinks Water far excels all other thing.
They that daily taste neat Wine
Virginity albeit some highly prize it
Compared with Marriage
Differs as much
Why then have at you in another kind.";"";"";"@001649_A11_D14 The City Gallant

One is no Number; Maydes are nothing then
Without the sweete societie of Men.
Wil thou liue single still? one shalt thou bee
Though neuer singling Hymen couple thee.
Wild Sauages that drinke of running Springs
Thinkes Water farre excells all other thing.
They that dayly taste neat Wine
Virginitie albeit some highly prize it
Compard with Marriag
Differs as much
Why then haue at you in another kind.";"Cooke

column1: I showed my passport humbled on my knee.

And begged that only she might give my doom.
Pluto was pleased and sealed it with a kiss.

And bad thee lead me through the gates of Horn:
Where dreams have passage in the silent night.

column1: Her fellow fiends do daily make complaint
<span class=""quote"">Unto grim Pluto
Of her unruly misbehaviour:
Intreating that a passport might be drawn
For her to wander till the day of doom
On earth again to vex the minds of men
And swore she was the fittest fiend in Hell
To drive men to desperation.
To this intent her passport straight was drawn
And in a whirlwind forth of Hell she came;
Over hills she hurls
The trees flew up with roots

column1: Friar Bacon reading one day of the many conquests of England
column2: bethought himself how he might keep it hereafter from the like conquests
column3: and so make himself famous hereafter to all posterities: This (after great study) he found could be no way so well done as one; which was <span class=""quote"">to make a head of Brass
column4: and if he could make this head to speak (and hear it when it speaks) then might he be able to wall all England about with Brass. To this purpose he got one Friar Bungey to assist him
column5: who was a great Scholar and a Magician

column1: Conditionally that thou wilt stay with me
And let Achates sail to Italy:
I'll give thee tackling made of riveiled gold
Wound on the harks of odoriferous trees;
Oars of massy ivory
Through which the water shall delight to play;
Thy anchors shall be hewed from crystal rooks
Which
The masts whereon thy swelling sails shall hang
Hollow pyramides of silver plate;
The sails of folded lawn
The wars of Troy
For ballast
Take what ye will
Achates

column2: be merry: we will hasten home

column1: So soon as King Marailiua will consent
To let his daughter wend with us to France.
Meanwhile we'll richly rig up all our Fleet
More brave than was that gallant Grecian keel
That brought away the Colchian fleece of gold:
Our sails of sendall spread into the wind;
Our ropes and tackling all of finest silke
Fetched from the native looms of labouring worms
The pride of Barbary
That is transported by the Western bounds;
Our stems cut out of gleaming Ivory;
Our planks and sides iramde out of Cypress wood
That bears the name of Cyparissus' Change
To burst the billows of the Ocean Sea
Where Phoebus dips his amber-tresses oft
And kisses Thetis in the day's decline;
That Neptune proud shall call his Tritons forth
To cover all the Ocean with a calm:
So rich shall be the rubbish of our barks
Ta'en here for ballast to the ports of France

That Charles himself shall wonder at the sight.";"";"#009003 Admiral's (The Prince's) Men / #009013 Queen's Men";"@000876_A91_D94 Orlando";"";"WoSp#004491 ship speech";"Work unmarked";"Author unmarked";"Romance";"";"Narrator";"BODY OF TEXT";"";"Secondary (Academic_Literature)";"@006268";"[...] And now

column1: So soone as King Marailiua will consent
To let his daughter wend with us to France.
Meane while weele richly rigge up all our Fleete
More brave than was that gallant Grecian keele
Tkat brought away the Colchyan fleece of gold:
Our sailes of sendall spread into the winde;
Our ropes and tackling all of finest silke
Fetcht from the native loomes of laboring wormes
The pride of Barbarie
That is transported by the Western bounds;
Our stems cut out of gleaming Iuorie;
Our planks and sides iramde out of Cypresse wood
That bears the name of Cyparissus Change
To burst the billows of the Ocean Sea
Where Phoebus dips his amber-tresses oft
And kisses Thetis in the daies decline;
That Neptune prowd shall call his Trytons forth
To oouer all the Ooean with a calme:
So rich shall be the rubbish of our barkes
Tane here for ballas to the ports of France
That Charles him selfe shall wonder at the sight.";"Greene

Let in the maid, that out a maid;"provisional";"_ 0_Anon";"Au jardin de mon père";"Anon.  ""Au jardin de mon père."" Popular French ballad.  Quoted in: H. R. D. Anders. Shakespeare's Books. Berlin: Georg Reimer
Le fils d'un avocat;
Que portez-vous la belle
Dans ce panier couvert?
Mignonne tant je vous aime
Mais vous ne m'aimez pas.
Monsieur ce sont des oranges
Ne vous en plaît-il pas?
Il en prend une couple
Dans son sein il les metta.
Mignonne tant je vous aime
Mais vous ne m'aimez pas.
Venez vous en la belle
On vous les paiera;
Elle y entra pucelle
Grossette elle en sorta.
Mignonne tant je vous aime

Mais vous ne m'aimez pas.";"This ballad is recorded in an album that belonged to a Dutch lady named Theodora Van Wassenaer in 1598.";"";"@006453 Popular French ballad";"";"SuId#030673 in a maid that out a maid";"Work unmarked";"Author unmarked";"Song or ballad";"";"Narrator";"BODY OF TEXT";"";"Secondary (Academic_Shakespeare)";"@010151-188.

column1: Le fils d'un avocat;
Que portez vous la belle
Dans ce panier couvert?
Mignone
Monsieur ce sont des orenges
Ne vous en plait-il pas?
Il en prend une couple
Dans son sein il les metta.
Mignone
Venez vous en la belle
On vous les payera;
Elle y entra pucelle
Grossette elle en sorta.
Mignone tant je vous ayme
Mais vous ne m'aymez pas.";"Anon.  ""Au jardin de mon père."" Traditional French ballad.  Quoted in: H. R. D. Anders. Shakespeare's Books. Berlin: Georg Reimer

column1:
Good men and true; stand together: hear your censure
what's thy judgement of Spenser?
[Iudicio:] A sweeter swan than ever song in Poe
A shriller Nightingale than ever blessed
The prouder groves of self admiring Rome.
Blith was each vally
While he did chant his rural minstrelsy.
Attentive was full many a dainty ear.
Nay hearers hung upon his melting tongue
While sweetly of his Faerie Queene he sung.
While to the waters fall he tun'd for fame
And in each bark engrav'd Eliza's name.
And yet for all this
Vnlac't the line of his desired life
Denying maintenance for his dear relief.
Careless care to prevent his exequy
Scarce deigning to shut up his dying eye.
[Ingenioso:] Pitty it is that gentler wits should breed
Where thick-skin chuffs laugh at a scholar's need.
But softly may our honour's ashes rest

That lie by merry Chaucer's noble chest.";"";"";"@001313_A02_D06 The Return from Parnassus Part 2";"";"NaHu#007001 Geoffrey Chaucer / NaHu_NewWot#007020 John Marston / NaHu#007026 Edmund Spenser / NaHu#007028 Henry Constable / NaHu#007029 John Davis / NaHu#007030 Thomas Lodge / NaHu#007032 Samuel Daniel / NaHu#007033 Christopher Marlowe / NaHu#007034 Thomas Watson / NaBo@005010 The Faerie Queene";"Work title";"Author name";"";"";"Dialogue";"BODY OF TEXT";"";"Electronic search (Fulltext database_Literature)";"@010001";"[Iudicio:] Turne ouer the leafe Ingenioso and thou shalt see the paynes of this worthy gentleman

column1:
Good men and true; stand togither: heare your censure
what's thy iudgement of Spencer?
[Iudicio:] A sweeter swan then euer song in Poe
A shriller Nightingale then euer blest
The prouder groues of selfe admiring Rome.
Blith was each vally
While he did chaunt his rurall minstralsye.
Attentiue was full many a dainty eare.
Nay hearers hong vpon his melting tong
While sweetly of his Faiery Queene he song.
While to the waters fall he tun'd for fame
And in each barke engrau'd Elizaes name.
And yet for all this
Vnlac't the line of his desired life
Denying mayntenance for his deare releife.
Carelesse care to preuent his exequy
Scarce deigning to shut vp his dying eye.
[Ingenioso:]
Pitty it is that gentler witts should breed
Where thickskin chuffes laugh at a schollers neede.
But softly may our honors ashes rest
That lie by mery Chaucers noble chest.";"84; act 1

column1: [Iudicio:] Sweet Constable doth take the wondering ear
And lays it up in willing 'prisonment:
Sweet honey dropping Daniel doth wage
War with the proudest big Italian
That melts his heart in sugared sonetting.
Only let him more sparingly make use
Of other's wit
column2: and use his own the more:

column1: That well may scorn base imitation.

Yet subiect to a Critics marginal.
Lodge for his ore in every paper boat
He that turns over Galen every day

To sit and simper Euphues' legacy.

column1: [Second Tailor:] Why you are his father.
[Third Tailor:] Pray who is fitter to act the son
That begot him.
[First Tailor:] Who shall act Prince Belthazer and the King?
[Third Tailor:] I will do Prince Belthazer too: and for the King
Who but I? which of you all has such a face for a King
Or such a leg to trip up the heels of a Traitor?
[Second Tailor:] You will do all I think.
